text: I may know why the spell check for English sometimes doesn't work in Firefox, maybe there's a dictionary conflict or something, because when I removed all the dictionaries, the spell check for English started working.
If you want to find out something interesting on Google, type "I'm feeling curious" or use this link https://www.google.com/search?q=I'm+feeling+curious
Tip about Google search and news. You don't need to read all the news, you can ask, "Top news stories this week" AI Overview will give you the answer.
Default styles for h1 elements are changing
Web design is thinking about how to make something better.
If a code seems unnecessary and you want to delete it, be careful because that code probably was used in other places.

Perhaps writing texts is an additional good practice for language learning. When you begin writing a text, then you start to think and look for words to use; this may refresh your memories of learned words, and you need to look for new words to use when writing a text, and to learn these new words.

I tried for several hours to add an SVG hamburger icon to the navigation (dropdown menu) and the attempt was unsuccessful, it does not work as it should (something was wrong with SVG and the click event using JS), so I left the text version.
SEO is when it takes 1 hour to come up with 2 words.
Web design news and UI/UX news are also news when big sites update their site design: changes in navigation, functionality, etc.
Caching pages and showing a fresh version of the page is probably a complicated thing.
Making changes to the code can often create bugs.

I think minimalism in web design is a skill that requires practice, training, and time. Simplicity doesn't mean little work, it's just as complex as a complex design with different effects.
+
Or maybe it's just the result of practice and your own style, your own evolution in design.
I finally figured out the difference between a blog and a microblog using search, microblog posts don't have a title.
Writing articles is not easy, it can take one day to write one very short article.
Having your own site means having control.
Even a very simple site requires many hours of work.
Site navigation is a complex thing.
Web design is the ability to identify flaws in a site's design.
The old code always looks more horrible than the new code after more experience.
Space in the code is important. (hint: Python)
I redesigned the blog from a static page to a more dynamic one (my JS script). Instead of one word in the post, post there will be consist with more words, this idea was bad with one word.
Restart if something doesn't work.

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "This galaxy's got its green for #StPatricksDay! ☘️ NGC 6822 is about 1.5 million light-years away. In this Webb composite image, its NIRCam instrument spotlights countless stars, while its MIRI instrument showcases the greenish-yellow, gas-rich regions: https://t.co/7jh078ledP https://t.co/TtZReh6OFK" / X
This galaxy is Kenough ⁣🩷 ⁣ Young and old stars shine together in one of our sky’s brightest galaxies, Messier  81 (M81), which lies 11.6… | Instagram
Roll out the red carpet! The stars are here. 🤩⁣ ⁣ Star-forming region NGC 604 contains more than 200 of the hottest, most massive kinds… | Instagram
These stars live in their own bubbles 🫧⁣ ⁣ A cloud of gas and dust full of bubbles is captured in this image from our Spitzer Space… | Instagram

Hubble on X: "Happy #JewelDay! 💎 Hubble observed a glittering piece of cosmic "jewelry" located 15,000 light-years away. Aptly nicknamed the Necklace Nebula, it was created by a pair of aging, tightly orbiting Sun-like stars that cast off an escaping ring of debris: https://t.co/mx7GfTpJ0j https://t.co/uakBAn678G" / X
Microsoft complies with EU's DMA, allowing uninstalling of OneDrive, Edge, Bing, and more | AlternativeTo

HUBBLE on X: "Our #HubbleTopImage features the dawn of a galactic collision 🌌. NGC 5256 is not one galaxy but two, in the process of a galactic collision. Read more: https://t.co/JcDmCao3fz 📷 @NASA , @ESA https://t.co/nO4nDOoQpd" / X
Web Design Curation Websites for Inspiration : r/web_design
If it is not possible to place the elements in an orderly or centered manner, place them in a random order.
The order of the style files in the header matters. Latter files overwrite the properties of earlier ones.

Taylor Swift on X: "Turns out it’s NOT the end of an era 😝 Miami, New Orleans, Indy and Toronto: The Eras Tour is coming to you in 2024 with @gracieabrams! Verified fan registration for all shows is open now - visit https://t.co/xw6YMN3GMc for more information https://t.co/DCgFQb2U22" / X
The symbol in the title before the text looks bad because there is already a symbol in front of it: the website icon.
25 Years in Search: The Most Searched - YouTube
On the most popular sites on the web, text aligns to the left in the input form. Those companies know better how to do that because they have many designers and researchers.
A Guided Tour of Apple Vision Pro - YouTube
A new way to Search: Circle to Search - YouTube

NASA Universe on X: "Did you know that the location of the @NASAHubble Legacy Field image was chosen because it had no bright sources? But it isn’t filled with "nothing"! There are more than 250,000 galaxies in the Hubble Legacy Field. https://t.co/PAawEFrA4U #NothingDay https://t.co/spG8MU05yD" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "We did the Monster Math. It was a star graveyard smash! A bizarre structure dubbed the “Green Monster” lurks in the remains of this exploded star. By combining Webb & @ChandraXray data, scientists may have found its source in a blast wave from the star: https://t.co/s2yyDsjGOt https://t.co/EPOBLRyxjv" / X

NASA JPL on X: "Jupiter sure is beautiful 🤩 If you’d like to get the latest images, news, and mission updates about this planet or the other beauties in our solar system delivered straight to your inbox – sign up for our newsletter! https://t.co/7OTd9Nk0tq https://t.co/oWrtJrN6UF" / X

Hubble on X: "Happy New Year's Eve! 🎉 You voted for NGC 1333 as our X audience's favorite 2023 Hubble image, so we're wrapping up the year with this stunning view of a star-forming region about 960 light-years away: https://t.co/r52aDgDPJD Here's to more science and discovery in 2024! https://t.co/0hnlSPS7WR" / X
HUBBLE on X: "🆕 It’s spoke season on Saturn! 🛞🪐 Saturn’s spokes are ephemeral features that move with its rings. Read more: https://t.co/2odgfecT1c and 🧵👇 https://t.co/u5Wxyt1Or5" / X
HUBBLE on X: "Our ESA/Hubble Picture of the Week features spiral galaxies which are not all they might appear 🌌 Read more: https://t.co/R2tfPx0hHE https://t.co/tEookVsxBy" / X
HUBBLE on X: "See the parade (of galaxies) go by! 🌌 Access more space-themed .gifs at our giphy page: https://t.co/lZxzq44LzA https://t.co/RLN97oXaZp" / X
gradient practice_ball
HUBBLE on X: "Our #HubbleTopImage shows the Serpens Nebula, a stellar nursery about 1300 light-years away. 🐍 Read more: https://t.co/VYp1ghaycM 📷 @NASA , @ESA and @stsci https://t.co/ZwZvqYHVwC" / X
Behance Blog | Top Visual Trends of 2023

HUBBLE on X: "Our #HubbleTopImage drifts through the vast Lagoon Nebula. This stellar nursery is alive with fierce winds from hot stars, swirling chimneys of gas, and energetic star formation ✨ Read more: https://t.co/ZkKZD4s3oy 📷 @NASA , @ESA, STScI https://t.co/QGgYRZ91Hr" / X
HUBBLE on X: "Our #HubbleTopImage showcases Westerlund 2, an immense cluster boasting approximately 3,000 stars. Read more: https://t.co/nppNU5Dxyn 1/2 https://t.co/CowjiWIV77" / X

Hubble on X: "We think the Orion Nebula looks like a cosmic turkey! 🦃 In reality, this is the closest major star-forming region to Earth at 1,500 light-years away: https://t.co/UaUmCwgN4G https://t.co/ZS9rniZD8x" / X

NASA en español on X: "¡Un descubrimiento revolucionario!Nuevos hallazgos de @NASAWebb respaldan la teoría que explica cómo se forman los planetas. Aprende más: https://t.co/8irqYd5Szi https://t.co/YH0kPbPw5n" / X

Hubble on X: "A solar-powered storm! ☀️ The planet Saturn has aurorae, seen as the bright blue glow in this #HubbleClassic image. These storms are driven mainly by the pressure of the solar wind, which is a stream of charged particles from the Sun: https://t.co/PVRNZr8PjK https://t.co/GLSNdqUw0Q" / X
NASA JPL on X: "It’s creepy and it’s kooky 👻 Even Jupiter is celebrating Halloween! More on this haunting #JunoCam image: https://t.co/lqxlxZokM2 https://t.co/aT4ZGkiYsj" / X

NASA JPL on X: "New view, who dis? Captured by @NASAWebb, this infrared perspective of the Crab Nebula shows never-before-seen details of an exploded star located 6,500 light-years away. https://t.co/r1C1OJfjm5 https://t.co/rsfoeJMwms" / X

Hubble Space Telescope on X: "Want to wow your friends? There are more hydrogen atoms in an ounce of water than there are stars in the observable universe. That’s a 1 followed by 24 zeros vs. a 1 followed by 21 zeros. And the glass of water is tiny—as small as 1 oz (30 ml). Stars: https://t.co/yTZ37izD8j https://t.co/6HRCF2DOXh" / X
Black Eye Galaxy – NGC 4826

Hubble on X: "Chomp, chomp... #HappyHalloween! Don't worry – this isn't a space monster devouring a star. This is CB 130-3, which is a compact mass of gas and dust known as a dense core. Learn more, if you dare: https://t.co/TIvwX20LEe https://t.co/2FkfFa4OhY" / X

Hubble on X: "A galaxy in all of its dusty glory! This #HubbleClassic image shows the giant elliptical galaxy NGC 1316. The complex loops of cosmic dust and star clusters shown in this image indicate the galaxy was formed from a past merger of two galaxies: https://t.co/nny92d7GFh https://t.co/gococmWu6H" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "Three explosions, two stars, and a rare discovery. Webb recently detected tellurium, an element rarer than platinum on Earth, in the explosive aftermath of two neutron stars merging. The detection may help reshape our understanding of the cosmos: https://t.co/lRPR89aGD0 Thread👇 https://t.co/bMtRGc6SlG" / X

HUBBLE on X: "2⃣✖️🌀 or 3⃣✖️🌀❓ Despite what first meets the eye in our ESA/Hubble Picture of the Week, the interacting galaxy pair known as Arp-Madore 2339-661 has three members. Did you spot the third galaxy? 🤔 1/3 https://t.co/8uAbR5z5QB" / X

NASA Sun & Space on X: "Happy #SunDay! This week’s space weather report includes: · 2 C-class flares · 0 M-class flares · 20 coronal mass ejections · 0 geomagnetic storms This video from NASA’s Solar Dynamics Observatory shows activity on the Sun over the past week. https://t.co/ZOn0BNwQb2" / X

Massive stars can wreak havoc on their surroundings, as seen in this view of the Carina nebula. The bright star at the center is one of the most massive in the galaxy. Its blinding glare is sculpting – and destroying – the surrounding nebula.

NASA Exoplanets on X: "👀Something's Watching👀 When we peered at the Helix nebula in infrared and other light, it appeared to be looking back. @NASA's space telescopes mapped the structure of the dying star unraveling into space – about 700 light-years away in the constellation Aquarius.… https://t.co/vrPejY1v78" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "Grim grinning ghosts 👻 Webb captured this spectral view of star-forming region NGC 346 in mid-infrared light. The blue tendrils represent silicates and sooty chemical molecules, while the red glow represents warm dust heated by bright, massive stars: https://t.co/ExyrIxSiJX https://t.co/0jyav1Du9Q" / X

Hubble on X: "Boomerang Nebula 🪃 Though this #HubbleClassic view almost resembles an hourglass or bow tie, it was given this nickname back in 1980 by astronomers using ground-based telescopes. Hubble's clear vision revealed more details about its shape: https://t.co/DsTpN2UTxH https://t.co/MdUJQ4cmH5" / X

Hubble on X: "Welcome to NGC 5068! Shining in this new Hubble image, this galaxy contains a bright central bar, which is a densely packed region of mature stars seen up top. A black hole lurks behind the bar, tugging the stars together with its gravitational pull: https://t.co/Tt096tHWUv https://t.co/b6mKMzlMJ2" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "What might a baby picture of our Sun look like? 👶 Seen in this Webb image is a newborn star with supersonic jets of gas spewing from its poles. It’s only a few tens of thousands of years old here, but when it grows up, it'll be much like our Sun: https://t.co/vOato50SeZ https://t.co/UhTX3jLnIr" / X

Hubble on X: "A peculiar pair! This #HubbleFriday image shows Arp 107, which is a pair of galaxies in the midst of a collision about 465 million light-years away. A faint "bridge" of dust and gas connects the two. Keep reading: https://t.co/HU7uZ6JKh2 https://t.co/6VVhxBYXyi" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "Ripple effect 🌀 Seen here by Webb's Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) is the galaxy M51, also known as NGC 5194. The gravity of its neighbor, the dwarf galaxy NGC 5195, is thought to be partially responsible for those prominent & distinct spiral arms! More: https://t.co/6i0ZsjGGuQ https://t.co/KAK7n191v5" / X

Hubble on X: "Since 1990, Hubble has observed Supernova 1987A. This wide-field view shows a bright ring around the central region of the exploded star that's made of material cast off by the star about 20,000 years before its death. More in this thread ⬇️ https://t.co/Ngi04NQu3Y" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "Floating like a cosmic jellyfish is the iconic supernova SN 1987A. Webb has given us the most clear & detailed look yet, revealing a new feature — small crescent-like structures thought to be part of the outer layers of gas shot out from the explosion: https://t.co/IJJAfRDXHG https://t.co/6Ct8T7EiMx" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on X: "There’s just one Ring Nebula to rule them all. Now Webb has turned its eye on this popular target, revealing the complexity of its structure in unprecedented detail — and the possibility that the dying star at its center has a companion: https://t.co/wfcaLkQNAe https://t.co/aA3pMDQArY" / X

Chandra Observatory on X: "Today Chandra is studying a galaxy cluster in Lyra. Nearby in the sky is NGC 6745. Shaped like the head of a bird about to grab a tasty bite of food, the galaxy's spiral shape has been distorted by a collision with a smaller galaxy located almost out of view on the lower right. https://t.co/ducoqNq6uI" / X
National Geographic on Twitter: "A lion cub rests on a tree branch in Serengeti National Park, Tanzania https://t.co/CaOZ7eyEFb" / X

Hubble on Twitter: "It's #HubbleFriday time! This week's new image shows the globular cluster NGC 6652. Globular clusters are roughly spherical groups of stars held together by their mutual gravitational attraction. NGC 6652 is about 30 million light-years away: https://t.co/9JpOi0ca9t https://t.co/DaL93KDdbd" / X
Jain - Makeba (Official Video) - YouTube

Chandra Observatory on Twitter: "This image of supernova remnant DEM L71 reveals an inner cloud of glowing iron and silicon in green and blue. The delicate looking red shell surrounding the cloud — an outer blast wave from the explosion of a white dwarf star — is approximately 60 light-years across. https://t.co/OiexjsGjkt" / X

Nat Geo WILD on Twitter: "These gorgeous blooms have us tickled pink 🌸 📸 1/4: A close view of the intense pink blooms of a plumeria plant. (National Geographic Image Collection/Jodi Cobb) https://t.co/EbT5PzdwRw" / X

NASA Webb Telescope on Twitter: "Going goblin mode. Within the orange-white splotch at the center of this image are 2 chaotic baby stars. Over thousands of years, the pair repeatedly gobbled up, then spat out the gas and dust around them — producing those fiery orange lobes: https://t.co/lSOy5uyCYD https://t.co/jHVu6YlGXv" / X
box-decoration-break - CSS: Cascading Style Sheets | MDN
repeat() - CSS: Cascading Style Sheets | MDN
scroll-padding-top - CSS: Cascading Style Sheets | MDN

NASA Webb Telescope on Twitter: "Cheers to our first year! 🥂 Let’s celebrate one year of Webb science by taking a brand-new look at Sun-like stars being born, in this detailed close-up of Rho Ophiuchi, the closest-star-forming region to Earth. https://t.co/jXJgjb4mFj https://t.co/yi891eVDHp" / Twitter
